# Types of Societies

## How do sociologists classify societies?

__Technological sophistication:__  Generally, the greater the level of technological sophistication, the *less* a society depends on environmental fluctuations.

## Preindustrial Societies

## Types of Preindustrial Societies

<div class="columns-2">

__Hunter-gathers__

- Most of human existence, up to about 10,000 years ago
- Highly-dependent on environment and avaialable resources
- *Wild* animals and plants
  
__Pastoralists__

- Animal husbandry of *domesticated* animal species
- Relatively mobile (searching for grazing land)
- Animals used for food/clothing/labor/transportation

## Types of Preindustrial Societies (cont.)

<div class="columns-2">

__Horticulturalists__

- Small patches of wild/domesticated plants; relatively simple tools, not very labor intenstive
- Supplements other subsistence strategies
- Associated with more-pemanent settlements

__Agriculturalists__

- Limited range of staple crops; surplus storage
- Larger, permanent settlements
- Non-food producers (i.e., craft specialists and elites)

__Feudal__

- Strict socio-economic hierarchy
- Lords (wealthy landowners) and peasants (worked land and received protection in return)

## Industrial Societies

<div class="columns-2">

Industrial Revolution begins in 18th century, continues into the 19th century

- First steam engine in 1782
- Mechanical power replaces human/animal power

<br>

Accompanied by other social changes...

- Population movements to urban centers
- Rural migrants faced over-crowding, poor living/working conditions, and poverty
- Aspirations of upward socio-economic mobility
- "Old" money challenged by "new" money
<br>

<font size=5 color="red">__Sociology develops in this social context.__</font>

## Post-industrial Societies

<div class="columns-2">

Also called __*information societies*__

Some general features...

- Decrease in production of material goods
- Increas in production of *information* and *services*
- Access to education more important (than in an industrial society)

## Roles and Status

What are __*roles*__?

- Patterns of behavior that we recognize in each other that are representative of a person's social status

What role are you currently playing?  What other roles do you play on a day-to-day basis?

<br>

What is __*status*__ to a sociologist?

- Describe the responsibilities and benefits that a person experiences according to their rank and role in society
- Ascribed vs. acheived status

Role strain and role conflict
